headline.main: HOW TO STOP SMOKING, FIGHT WITHDRAWAL AND STILL END UP TRIMMER THAN YOU STARTED OUT

docs.lead_paragraph: IS your conscience saying that quitting smoking should be one of your New Year's resolutions? At the same time, are you afraid to let go of cigarettes - the things that pick you up and calm you down perhaps 20 or more times a day? And are you afraid that, without cigarettes to relax you and keep your mouth and hands busy, you will eat until you blossom into a human version of the Goodyear blimp? If any of these conditions apply to you, the experiences of one former smoker and tips from several experts may help you shed your dependence on cigarettes and enable you to end up even trimmer than you started out. Janet Quinn had smoked 30 or more cigarettes a day for more years than she cares to admit. As a professor of nursing at the University of South Carolina, she knew more than most smokers why she should quit, and she had tried to stop three times. Each time she lasted about a month, until the struggle wore her down so much that she started smoking again.
